unnormalised: Air quality remains a significant environmental concern across India, particularly in densely populated urban areas. The Air Quality Index (AQI) is a crucial tool for understanding the levels of pollutants in the air we breathe. An AQI of 0-50 is considered good, while anything above 300 is hazardous.
normalised: Air quality remains a significant environmental concern across India, particularly in densely populated urban areas. The Air Quality Index (A Q I) is a crucial tool for understanding the levels of pollutants in the air we breathe. An A Q I of zero to fifty is considered good, while anything above three hundred is hazardous.

unnormalised: Major pollutants contributing to poor air quality include particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM10), nitrogen dioxide (NO2), and ozone (O3). Sources range from vehicle emissions and industrial activities to construction dust and burning of agricultural residue, particularly after the harvest season.
